DataElement.preferredDefinition: information related to the result of a medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for platelets, irregular, disc-shaped fragments of large bone marrow cells called megakaryocytes in the blood that assist in blood clotting._A specific reason explaining why a meaningful value is not available.  A meaningful value answers the question posed by a Data Element Concept.  In contrast, a Missing Value Reason answers the implicit question "Why is there no 'meaningful' value?", when there is none._An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the result of a medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for platelets, irregular, disc-shaped fragments of large bone marrow cells called megakaryocytes in the blood that assist in blood clotting.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredDefinition: platelet. An irregularly shaped disklike cytoplasmic fragment of a megakaryocyte that is shed in the marrow sinus and subsequently found in the peripheral blood where it functions in clotting. A platelet contains granules in the central part (granulomere) and, peripherally, clear protoplasm (hyalomere), but no definite nucleus; is about one-third to one-half the size of an erythrocyte; and contains no hemoglobin. (STED98):Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: An irregular, disc-shaped element in the blood that assists in blood clotting. Platelets are not blood cells, they are fragments of large bone marrow cells called megakaryocytes.
